toc_entry.title: Hail To Thee, George E. Fischer
toc_entry.description: Most of the time you're a nice, ordinary businessman. But for one brief, shining moment you were King antonio, monarch of San antonio’s Fiesta and semi-beloved ruler of the one Texas city that still loves a good king.

toc_entry.title: Hell On Wheels
toc_entry.description: In which John Howard, our toughest athlete, goes after a world bicycle record and hopes america will care.

toc_entry.title: The New Rustlers
toc_entry.description: Today's desperadoes are in the bays of the Texas coast, roping redfish and cursing the Parks and Wildlife Department.

toc_entry.title: The Farm-To-Market Road
toc_entry.subtitle: Texas Primer
toc_entry.description: The last best way to see the real Texas.

toc_entry.title: Tricks
toc_entry.description: On the first day of april my true love gave to me . . . nineteen gifts that weren’t what they appeared to be.

toc_entry.title: “What I Admire I Must Possess”
toc_entry.description: Dominique de Menil loves beautiful things and interesting people. In forty years of collecting them she has changed Houston.

toc_entry.title: Big Wheels And the Silver Spike
toc_entry.subtitle: Texana
toc_entry.description: It wasn’t business that drew the state’s top politicians to a Trans-Pecos ranch. Their mission: to mark the centennial of the train that linked Texas to the West.

toc_entry.title: Have Ladle, Will Travel
toc_entry.subtitle: Food
toc_entry.description: Culinary one-upmanship has produced the designer chef, a food whiz who comes from afar to lend prestige and panache to Texas’ ritziest eateries.

toc_entry.title: Down With Compromise
toc_entry.subtitle: Jazz
toc_entry.description: Freddie Hubbard’s attempts to play pop music have been disastrous. But when he tackles a pure mainstream sound, he shows what jazz trumpeting is all about.

toc_entry.title: Oil Rigged
toc_entry.subtitle: Books
toc_entry.description: The Great Energy Scam purports to uncover the collusion of the feds and the oil companies, but the real scandal is what the author overlooks. Yet another book on killer Ted Bundy sheds no light on his crimes. Roughneck is a rousing look at america’s most radical labor union.

toc_entry.title: Scotch, Neat
toc_entry.subtitle: Movies
toc_entry.description: Local Hero is undiluted pleasure. Lianna is a little watered-down.

toc_entry.title: Curtains!
toc_entry.subtitle: Classical Music
toc_entry.description: Once touted, now routed, San antonio’s opera takes its last bow.

toc_entry.title: Around the State
toc_entry.description: A selective statewide guide to amusements and events.

toc_entry.title: Reporter
toc_entry.description: Times are tough in Laredo; specialty advertisers are unveiled in Dallas; some very old bones stir things up in Leander; a wild turkey comes back to West Texas; newspapers go wild in San antonio.

toc_entry.title: State Secrets
toc_entry.description: Southwest Airlines’ California gamble pays off—and Texans do the paying; update from Gibgate; why Bellaire is not Park Place; a truly dumb idea from UT.
